title: Oinochoe (Pitcher) in the Shape of a Female Head

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of terracotta, red-figure.

artist_display:
Attributed to the Canessa Class
Greek; Athens
description: Three manufacturing techniques were employed to produce this vessel. The lower portion, in the shape of a woman’s face, was made in a mold; the shoulder, neck, and mouth of the pitcher were formed on a potter’s wheel; and the handle was fashioned by hand. The woman's flesh and thick, centrally parted hair are the natural color of the clay, but her brows and the contours of her eyes and irises are drawn in black. Her sclerae are white, and her irises are brown.
publication_history:
Collection Eugène Piot: Antiquités, 18 July 1890 (Paris 1890), no. 174.

Daniel Catton Rich, “Three Plastic Vases in the Classical Collection,” Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago 24, 6 (1930), p. 75, (fig. on left, p. 75).

John D. Beazley, Attic Red-figure Vase Painters (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1963), p. 1548, no. 17 (inv. no. wrongly given as 11.824).

Karen B. Alexander, "From Plaster to Stone: Ancient Art at the Art Institute of Chicago," in Karen Manchester, Recasting the Past: Collecting and Presenting Antiquities at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago; New Haven: Yale University Press, 2012), p. 25.
exhibition_history:
Art Institute of Chicago, The Human Figure in Early Greek Art, A Preview, Part One, Gallery 101A, September 1, 1988 – May 24, 1989.  

Art Institute of Chicago, Of Gods and Glamour: The Mary and Michael Jaharis Galleries of Greek, Roman, and Byzantine Art, Gallery 151, November 11, 2012 - present.
provenance_text: Eugène Piot (1812-1890), Paris; sold, Hôtel Drouot, Paris, May 27-30, 1890, lot 174, to Charles L. Hutchinson (1854-1924) and Martin A. Ryerson (1856-1932), Chicago; on loan to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1890-1905; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1905.
department_title: Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium
category_titles: Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium

input: Oinochoe (Pitcher) in the Shape of a Female Head
